contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) this is a simile, and the Spirit descended upon Jesus like a bird descends from the sky toward the ground or 2) the Spirit literally looked like a dove as he descended upon Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: the Spirit coming down on him like a dove

contextId.information: Jesus compares the people to sheep who are confused when they do not have their shepherd to lead them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: they were like sheep without a shepherd

contextId.information: The man sees men walking around, yet they are not clear to him, so he compares them to trees. AT: "Yes, I see people! They are walking around, but I cannot see them clearly. They look like trees." (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: I see men who look like walking trees

contextId.information: The boy's appearance is compared to that of a dead person. AT: "The boy appeared dead" or "The boy looked like a dead person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: The boy looked like one who was dead

contextId.information: Jesus is comparing how people must receive the kingdom of God to how little children would receive it. AT: "in the same manner as a child would" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

Jesus uses this simile to compare how people are to love each other with the same love as they love themselves. AT: "love your neighbor as much as you love yourself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

This simile compares how people are to love each other with the same love that they love themselves. AT: "to love your neighbor as much as you love yourself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: to love one's neighbor as oneself
